repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Second East Java Urban
            Development Project, Bali Urban Infrastructure Project and
            Municipal Innovations Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second East Java Urban Development
            Project had a moderately satisfactory outcome and modest
            institutional development impact. The Bali Urban
            Infrastructure Project also had a moderately satisfactory
            outcome but its institutional development impact is
            substantial. The Municipal Innovations Project had a
            satisfactory outcome with modest institutional development
            impact. All three projects have unlikely sustainability. The
            performances of the Bank and the Borrower for all three
            projects were satisfactory.  Experience with the three
            projects suggests the following lessons: 1) Local
            governments should continue to build upon their demonstrated
            capacity to improve infrastructure delivery, but need to be
            more responsive to urban development needs expressed through
            local community participation. 2) A cross-sector framework,
            such as the Integrated Urban Infrastructure Development
            Program (IUIDP), can work well for local governments,
            provided the investment resources within it are sufficiently
            concentrated to adequately address needs in all included
            sectors. 3) All stakeholders, including local governments
            themselves, need to agree and clearly understand the purpose
            behind local innovations - be it to increase efficiency, to
            increase client-responsiveness. 4) The Bank should ensure
            that local governments are always included as partners, as
            it continues to emphasize improving their performance in
            service delivery. 5) Monitoring and Evaluation systems need
            to be designed and implemented to track outcomes related to
            project objectives, as well as the inputs and outputs of
            project activities that will help achieve these outcomes.

repnme.cdata!: Indonesia - second Java Urban Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated as
            satisfactory, while sustainability is likely. Bank and
            Borrower performances are assessed as satisfactory overall.
            Several lessons were learned: The possibiliy of external
            shocks, and their likely impact on project implementation,
            should be incorporated specifically in the risk analysis of
            future projects. The decentralized approach used in this
            project has proven superior to centralized management and
            should be fostered and maintained wherever adequate human
            resources are available. The Government of Indonesia and the
            provincial government should try to identify the main
            reasons for the generally disappointing project
            implementation performance of Malang City, and draw
            conclusions. Both levels of government and the Bank should
            cooperate in defining a strategy for future financial
            assistance to East Java, to fit with the Government of
            Indonesia's and provincial priorities, and with the
            Bank's Country Assistance Strategy (CAS). The
            Government and the Bank should try to identify a more
            promising approach in the sanitation sector, because many
            investments made under this project do not seem to show the
            desired sustainability. The two parties should continue to
            cooperate in designing a viable water supply policy,
            including the careful monitoring of the institutional
            development of the water enterprises owned by the local
            government (PDAMs), and should jointly decide on the
            appropriate criteria for defining further financial assistance.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Second East Java Urban
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The medium-term development objectives
            of the Second East Java Urban Development Project are to: 1)
            improve urban infrastructure service delivery; and 2)
            develop necessary financial and institutional capacity in
            local governments to sustain urban services. The project
            consists of the following components: 1) infrastructure
            investment in: (a) urban roads and traffic management; (b)
            water supply; (c) solid waste management; (d) human waste
            disposal/sanitation; (e) urban drainage/flood control; (f)
            urban renewal; and (g) Kampung Improvement Program/Market
            Infrastructure Improvement Program; 2) incremental
            operations and maintenance on existing and new
            infrastructure; and 3) implementation support including
            local management and administration and technical assistance.
